intro.tagline: From framework overload to one simple management system.
intro.description: USM (Unified Service Management) is a method that gives any service organization a single, universal way to organize work. Instead of juggling dozens of frameworks and tools, USM gives you one architecture, one process model, and eight reusable workflows that fit all services – IT, HR, building management, catering, telecom, and more.

audiences.title: Leaders & Executives
audiences.text: Understand USM as a management system that increases control, improves quality, and reduces waste – without drowning your teams in theory.

audiences.title: Service & Process Managers
audiences.text: Learn how five universal processes and eight workflows can replace complex, siloed practices and turn them into one coherent way of working.

audiences.title: Practitioners & Coaches
audiences.text: Get practical patterns, visuals, and examples you can use tomorrow in workshops, training, and real-life transformations.

processModel.intro: USM organizes all service work with a very small set of building blocks: five universal processes and eight reusable workflows. Think of it as a train: five carriages (processes) always running on the same track (your managed infrastructure and governance). The workflows are the standard journeys that calls take through this train.

processes.name: Agree – Contract & Demand Management
processes.short: Agree on services and value with customers and suppliers.
processes.purpose: CTM structures the relationship with customers and suppliers. It translates mission, vision, and strategy into concrete service agreements (SAs), OLAs, and underpinning contracts (UCs).
examples: Defining a new service together with a business unit.
Negotiating service levels and opening hours.
Reviewing service reports with the customer and adjusting agreements.

processes.name: Change – Realizing Improvements & New Services
processes.short: Implement changes in a controlled way.
processes.purpose: CHM handles all structural changes to services, infrastructure, and routines. It converts ideas, requirements, and risks into implemented improvements while controlling impact and risk.
examples: Rolling out a new HR self-service portal.
Upgrading core network components.
Standardizing a recurring change as a change template.

processes.name: Recover – Incident Management
processes.short: Restore service quickly when something breaks.
processes.purpose: INC deals with disruptions and incidents. The primary goal is to restore service as quickly as possible, with minimal impact on customers and users.
examples: Solving a major network outage.
Helping a user who cannot access a critical application.
Triggering a problem or risk investigation after repetitive incidents.

processes.name: Operate – Day-to-Day Operations
processes.short: Execute planned, recurring, and ad-hoc operational work.
processes.purpose: OPS manages all planned and operational tasks, such as maintenance, standard service requests, housekeeping tasks, and monitoring responses.
examples: Provisioning a new laptop based on a standard request.
Carrying out weekly backup checks or building inspections.
Performing preventive maintenance on key facilities.

processes.name: Improve – Risk & Improvement Management
processes.short: Continuously improve services and reduce risks.
processes.purpose: RIM structurally handles risks, bottlenecks, and improvement ideas. It evaluates where things can be better, prioritizes, and feeds improvements into CTM or CHM.
examples: Running a periodic risk inventory and prioritizing improvements.
Analysing recurring incidents and addressing the structural cause.
Tracking improvement sprints and their effect on KPIs and KRIs.

processModel.workflowsIntro: The five processes are the ‘cars of the train’. The eight workflows are the standard routes that calls follow through those cars. Every call in your service organization – no matter the domain – can be mapped to one of these eight workflows.

workflows.name: Wishes & Requirements
workflows.short: From new idea to agreed requirement.
workflows.typicalStart: Customer or internal stakeholder expresses a wish, idea, or requirement.
examples: A business unit requests a new reporting capability.
HR asks for a new onboarding package for employees.

workflows.name: New or Changed Service
workflows.short: From agreed requirement to implemented change.
workflows.typicalStart: An agreed requirement or improvement decision triggers a change.
examples: Implementing a new SaaS solution.
Standardizing and rolling out a new workspace concept.

workflows.name: Incident / Disruption
workflows.typicalStart: A user reports something is broken or monitoring detects an error.
examples: Resolving a major system outage.
Restoring access for a locked-out user.

workflows.name: Service Request
workflows.short: From request to fulfilled standard service.
workflows.typicalStart: A user asks for something standard and pre-agreed.
examples: Requesting a new laptop or mobile phone.
Booking a meeting room with catering.
Onboarding a new employee with a standard package.

workflows.name: Planned Operational Work
workflows.short: From plan to executed recurring tasks.
workflows.typicalStart: Periodic or scheduled work from plans and calendars.
examples: Weekly backup checks.
Monthly safety inspections.
Quarterly patching windows.

workflows.name: Monitoring & Events
workflows.typicalStart: Automated or manual monitoring detects an event or threshold breach.
examples: System monitoring raises a capacity alert.
Energy monitoring shows abnormal consumption.

workflows.name: Risks & Improvements
workflows.short: From finding a risk to implemented improvement.
workflows.typicalStart: Risks, trends, or improvement ideas are logged and evaluated.
examples: Security risk identified in an external audit.
Process bottleneck found in a USM Panel session.

workflows.name: Questions & Information
workflows.short: From question to clear answer or direction.
workflows.typicalStart: User, customer, or stakeholder asks for clarification or advice.
examples: Customer asks whether a service can support a new business scenario.
User asks how to use a facility correctly.

chapters.title: Chapter 1 – Why USM?
chapters.summary: Explains why service organizations struggle with complexity, framework overload, and fragmented practices – and how USM addresses this with one universal management system.
keyPoints: Fragmented frameworks create local optimizations and global chaos.
USM provides a simple, architectural approach instead of more practices.
The focus shifts from tools and silos to integrated service delivery.

chapters.title: Chapter 2 – Principles & Architecture
chapters.summary: Describes the core principles behind USM and shows how an enterprise service management architecture can be used for any service domain.
keyPoints: USM is based on a small set of strong, generic principles.
Architecture comes before practices: build the engine before polishing the dashboard.
The same architecture can support IT, HR, facilities, telecom, and more.

chapters.title: Chapter 3 – Services & Value
chapters.summary: Explores how services create value in co-creation with customers, and how USM uses a customer-driven, service-dominant logic.
keyPoints: A service is a promise of value, not just a product or system.
The customer’s context and perception determine value.
USM structures agreements and expectations to support co-creation of value.

chapters.title: Chapter 4 – People & Roles
chapters.summary: Clarifies how tasks, authorities, and responsibilities (TAR) are organized through roles, profiles, and teams.
keyPoints: Separate roles (what) from people (who) and teams (where).
Use RACI and profiles to keep responsibilities clear and balanced.
Matrix organization: process logic crosses hierarchical structures.

chapters.title: Chapter 5 – The USM Process Model
chapters.summary: Introduces the five generic processes and eight workflows that structure all work in a service organization.
keyPoints: Five processes: Agree, Change, Recover, Operate, Improve.
Eight workflows describe all standard ‘routes’ for calls.
Uniform workflows simplify training, tooling, reporting, and improvement.

chapters.title: Chapter 6 – Routines & Workflows
chapters.summary: Shows how processes, procedures, and work instructions are simplified into reusable workflows and templates.
keyPoints: Workflows are the practical ‘how’ of USM in daily work.
Standardization reduces variation and increases control.
Templates and patterns make it easy to reuse good routines.

chapters.title: Chapter 7 – The Service Organization
chapters.summary: Connects mission, vision, governance, policies, structures, and teams with USM’s way of organizing work.
keyPoints: From mission and core values to concrete objectives and policies.
Governance sets the environment; management runs the daily cycle.
Domain separation, process-based working, and RACI support control and assurance.

chapters.title: Chapter 8 – Technology Resources
chapters.summary: Describes the tools, databases, and templates that support USM – especially the service delivery coordination (SDC) tool and the managed infrastructure register (MIR).
keyPoints: Tooling must follow the method, not the other way around.
A good SDC tool supports all workflows in one database.
The MIR is the central register of all managed infrastructure components (MICs).

chapters.title: Chapter 9 – Deploying USM
chapters.summary: Explains how to introduce USM in a real organization using phased deployment, improvement sprints, and strong organizational change management.
keyPoints: Deployment is learning to apply USM, not installing a tool.
Use improvement sprints to combine process, people, tooling, and services.
USM plays nicely with Agile, DevOps, Lean, and Design Thinking.

practicalGuide.title: USM Practical Guide
practicalGuide.intro: Turn the USM method into concrete steps you can apply in your organization. The practical guide focuses on doing, not just knowing.

sections.title: Step 1 – Clarify Your Services & Customers
items: List your key services and their customers.
Capture why each service exists and what value it promises.
Sketch your current ‘service train’: who talks to whom and where work gets stuck.

sections.title: Step 2 – Map Your Work to the 5 Processes
items: Take a few weeks of tickets / tasks and classify them to CTM, CHM, INC, OPS, and RIM.
Notice where work is missing clear ownership or bounces between teams.
Use this map as a baseline to introduce the USM process model.

sections.title: Step 3 – Standardize Your 8 Workflows
items: Pick one workflow (for example incidents) and design the standard route for a call.
Define simple templates for classification, assignment, and communication.
Gradually apply the same thinking to all eight workflows.

sections.title: Step 4 – Align People, Roles & RACI
items: Create a lightweight RACI for your core processes and workflows.
Check for conflicts in TAR (for example, same person specifying and approving).
Adjust team responsibilities so every call type has clear ownership.

sections.title: Step 5 – Tune Your Tooling & MIR
items: Configure your service desk / SDC tool to follow the USM workflows.
Make sure there is one integrated call database and one MIR structure.
Use reports to focus on value, flow, and improvement, not just volumes.

sections.title: Step 6 – Run Improvement Sprints
items: Use short sprints (e.g. 8–12 weeks) to improve one aspect at a time.
Involve a USM-style Panel of operators and process managers.
Measure outcomes with simple KPIs/KRIs that matter to customers.

faq.q: Is USM another framework like ITIL or COBIT?
faq.a: No. USM is a method and architecture for how you organize and manage services. You can still use ITIL, COBIT, ISO standards, DevOps, Lean, and Agile practices – but USM gives you one simple management system underneath them all.

faq.q: Can USM be used outside IT?
faq.a: Yes. USM is domain-independent by design. It can be applied in IT, HR, facilities, security, telecom, municipalities, hospitals, universities, and more – anywhere you deliver services.

faq.q: Do we need a new tool to start with USM?
faq.a: Not necessarily. You can start with your current tools as long as you are willing to configure them to follow USM’s processes and workflows. At some point, you may want an SDC tool that supports USM natively to go further.
